p: While difficult to grow in cell culture, MERS CoV may be diagnosed by RT-PCR on respiratory secretions. Virus has been detected with these techniques in urine and stool as well. To increase the yield of testing, it is recommended that multiple specimens from different sites (e.g., nasopharyngeal swab, sputum, BAL fluid, serum, and stool) be tested using RT-PCR, which is available from the CDC and local health departments in the USA [ 37]. Due to the risk of transmission of infection to health care workers, contact and airborne precautions are recommended in caring for the suspected MERS-CoV infected patient [ 39, 40].
